Meeting a Specification

Most programmers do not write an entire piece of software by themselves. Big projects are written by big teams of programmers, and responsibilities are broken into class-sized chunks so that individuals may tackle small problems independently. The effect is good: no one programmer gets overwhelmed by the immensity of the problem, and bugs are easier to track since classes can be tested independently to make sure they do their jobs.

Your task now is to write a class that will plug in to a framework built by other programmers. You will be given only a specification that dictates what your class must do. You will combine your code with the others' code to make a complete working piece of software, but you will never see any source code but your own.
